ario is the failure of the storage tank when filled to the greatest amount, which would release 218,450 pounds of anhydrous ammonia; this represents the volume of the largest storage tank administratively limited at 85% of capacity. The release event was calculated assuming a windspeed of 1.5 meters per second (3.4 miles per hour) and a stability class F atmosphere (nighttime, light windspeed, no or little cloud cover).

The Alternative Release Scenario, based on the hazard review (i.e., a more plausible potential incident), is a 26,638 lbs release from a broken 3-inch diameter hose (or pipe) with a wind speed of 3 meters per second (6.7 miles per hour) and Pasquill Class D stability modeling parameters. 
~~
AQUA AMMONIA - Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios. 
The Worst-Case Release Scenario is the failure of the largest storage tank when filled to the greatest amount, which would release 501,600 pounds of aqua ammonia (equivalent to 122,100 lbs of NH3) within a secondarily contain berm with a net evaporative area of 5,595 square feet. The release event was calculated assuming a windspeed of 1.5 meters per second (3.4 miles per hour) and a stability class F atmosphere (nighttime, light windspeed, no or little cloud cover).

The Alternative Release Scenario, based on the hazard review (i.e., a more plausible potential incident), is a release from a broken 3-inch diameter hose (or pipe) with a wind speed of 3 meters per second (6.7miles per hour) and Pasquill Class D stability modeling parameters.

ES  4.0 | FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia, aqua ammonia, or regulated pesticides during the last five years resulting in death, injuries, evacuation(s), a shelter in-place order, or property or environmental damage.
~~~~~
ES  5.0 | THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The facilitys emergency response program is developed in accordance with Section 25503, Division 6.95 of the California Health and Safety Code, Hazardous Materials Business Plan requirements. The Maxwell Facility developed an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) in accordance with the requirements presented in the CalARP regulations §2745.8. The ERP is reviewed with operations staff on an annual basis and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release of a regulated substance.
~~~~~
ES  6.0 | PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Safety improvement is an on-going process at the Facility. Periodic evaluations will be performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. Specific changes to the anhydrous ammonia, aqua ammonia, and regulated pesticides processes at the Facility will be implemented as needed.
~~~~~
ES  7.0 | THE WORST-CASE RELEASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS
The worst-case release scenario and the alternative release scenario were evaluated for each of the regulated processes. The results of the evaluation are provided in the Risk Management Plan (RMP).

ANHYDROUS AMMONIA - Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios. 
The Worst-Case Release Scen

Participation Program in place and has implemented procedures regarding engaging employees for their input, as well as ensuring access to safety documentation to ensure consideration of their knowledge and experience in all applicable areas of the prevention program.

HOT WORK PERMIT:
With regard to hot work that may occur on or near the Anhydrous Ammonia Process, the Facility has developed a written Hot Work Permit program and procedure to document the evaluation of the fire prevention and protection requirements. 

CONTRACTOR SAFETY:
The contractors used by the Facility for anhydrous ammonia delivery have been informed regarding the known potential fire, explosion, or toxic release hazards related to delivery of anhydrous ammonia to the Facility. The Facility has confirmed that the delivery contractors have provided the appropriate training to their drivers regarding the delivery of anhydrous ammonia. The Facility also qualifies contractors who are engaged in maintaining the anhydrous ammonia systems to ensure that equipment is modified or repaired and returned to service safely.
 
OTHER CODE APPLICABILITY:
The Facility implements the provisions of the following guidelines, regulations, and standards for these regulated substances (partial list):
REGULATED SUBSTANCES
>     United States Department of Labor, Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) §1910.38, Employee emergency response plan and fire prevention plans
>     United States Department of Labor, Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR §1910.119, Process safety management of highly hazardous chemicals
>     United States Environmental Protection Agency (U.S. EPA), 40 CFR Chapter 1, Subchapter C, Part 68, Subpart E, Emergency Response

ANHYDROUS AMMONIA
>     United States Department of Labor, Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR §1910.111, Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia
>     California Occupational

tal release. The maintenance and mechanical integrity program include equipment inspection, preventative maintenance, recordkeeping, and training.

MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE:
Operation, safety, and environmental issues must be reviewed prior to initiation of a process change to ensure that those issues do not compromise the safety and integrity of the Anhydrous Ammonia Process, and to minimize adverse effects to worker safety and public health. The Management of Change (MOC) procedures are used to evaluate all changes to process materials, controls, equipment, and procedures.

PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEW:
The pre-startup safety review (PSSR) applies to additions or modifications to the Anhydrous Ammonia Process that require the safety information to be revised or updated. Whenever changes in affected processes are identified or planned, they must be evaluated as to the need for a PSSR. This assessment is undertaken in conjunction with the MOC review. The PSSR is performed in conjunction with the MOC review when the proposed change requires modifications to the safety procedures.

COMPLIANCE AUDITS:
Periodic compliance audits to assess the effectiveness of the written plan must be conducted every three years. Records of the audits and follow-up documentation are maintained to indicate findings and resolution of findings. In addition to internal compliance audits, the facility is subject to audits by the local Certified Unified Program Agency (CUPA) and Cal/OSHA.

INCIDENT INVESTIGATION:
Although no incidents involving regulated substances have occurred at the Facility in the last five years, an incident investigation program is in place. The program includes investigation requirements and reporting and would be implemented in the event of an incident.

EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION:
The Facility must rely upon the operational expertise and training of its employees at all levels and disciplines to ensure safe operation of the Anhydrous Ammonia Process. The Facility has an Employee

as implemented the following prevention program elements.
PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION:  
The Facility ensures that information concerning covered processes and regulated substances are up-to-date and available for review by employees. The Facility reviews the safety information during annual system operator training. 

PROCESS HAZARDS ANALYSIS / HAZARD REVIEW:  
The Facility conducts a hazard review of the anhydrous ammonia, aqua ammonia, and pesticides processes every five years or as needed by changes in the processes. The Facility uses the American Institute of Chemical Engineers (AIChE) Hazard and Operability Study (HazOps) methodology for the review of the regulated substances and processes. Results indicate that no high-risk hazards were identified through the hazard review.

OPERATING PROCEDURES:
Written operating procedures have been developed for the covered processes and are reviewed and revised as needed. The operating procedures are reviewed on an annual basis and re-certified upon review and/or modification. 

TRAINING:
Maxwell Facility and Grow West corporate staff understand that incidents involving the accidental release of regulated substances can be reduced by having trained operations and maintenance staff. A training program, which incorporates specific operating procedures and safe work practices, is an essential element of an effective prevention program. The training program is reviewed prior to the annual refresher training. The current training program is comprised of the following:
1. Initial employee training.
2. Periodic refresher training.
3. Training provided as a result of a new equipment addition or modification.
4. Competency testing involving written tests and observation following training.
5. Training records for each employee.

MAINTENANCE AND MECHANICAL INTEGRITY:

Anhydrous ammonia can be directly applied to the soil as a nutrient. 
>     Anhydrous ammonia (NH3) is converted to aqua ammonia (NH4OH). 
>     1The storage vessel information is presented below. 

Vessel          Capacity               Volume                Amount of NH3 
Bullet 1       15,000 gals          12,750 gals          65,535 lbs
Bullet 2       18,000 gals          15,300 gals          78,642 lbs
Bullet 3       50,000 gals          42,500 gals          218,450 lbs
Total            83,000 gals          70,550 gals          362,267 lbs

The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia handled is 362,267 pounds.
~~
AQUA AMMONIA
>     Aqua ammonia (NH4OH) is prepared, stored, and distributed for direct application as crop production nutrients.
>     The Facility produces aqua ammonia at a solution strength of 24.3% in the site in the converter. 
>     The aqua ammonia is stored in steel tanks at the site. The storage tanks are connected using a piping manifold. The tank valves are kept closed unless actively being filled or drained.
>     The aqua ammonia storage tank information is presented below. 

Vessel          Capacity          Net Capacity          Mass of NH4OH          Mass of NH3
Tank 1          66,000 gals     66,000 gals              501,600 lbs                  122,100 lbs
Tank 2          66,000 gals     66,000 gals              501,600 lbs                  122,100 lbs
Tank 3          66,000 gals     66,000 gals              501,600 lbs                  122,100 lbs
Tank 4          66,000 gals     66,000 gals              501,600 lbs                  122,100 lbs
Total            264,000 gals   264,000 gals          2,006,400 lbs                488,400 lbs

The maximum quantity of aqua ammonia that could be present onsite is 2,006,400 pounds. The amount of ammonia (as NH3) contained within the aqua ammonia solution, if all the tanks were filled to maximum capacity, is 488,4004 pounds.

ES  3.0 - ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
The Facility h

ES  1.0 | FACILITY ACCIDENTAL RELEASE POLICY
The owners, management, and employees of the Grow West Maxwell Facility, (herein referred to as the Maxwell Facility or Facility) at 5701 Maxwell Road, Maxwell, California 95955 are committed to the prevention of accidental release of anhydrous ammonia, aqua ammonia, and regulated pesticides. If an accidental release should occur, the Facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment. The Facility has developed a detailed Emergency Response Plan (ERP) and that plan will be implemented in the event of an accidental release.
~~~~~
ES  2.0 | FACILITY INFORMATION
The Facility is a retail agricultural facility whose primary activity is the storage and sale of fertilizers in addition to the sale of pre-packaged chemicals to agricultural operations in the Sacramento Valley of Northern California. The applicable North America Industrial Classification System (NAICS) code for this facility include 42491 (Farm Supplies Merchant Wholesalers). The Facility carries the U.S. EPA Facility Identifier number 1000-0018-2116.

The Maxwell Facility has ammonia, in both anhydrous and aqua ammonia forms, present at various times during the calendar year as a Regulated Substance (RS) in quantities that exceed federal and State of California threshold quantities.
~~
ANHYDROUS AMMONIA
>     Anhydrous ammonia (NH3) is a liquefied, compressed gas. 
>     Anhydrous ammonia is received by truck and stored in three storage tanks (bullets).  Anhydrous ammonia is loaded into a 50,000-gallon storage tank (bullet) and later transferred to either one 15,000-gallon storage tank or one 18,000-gallon storage tank.
>     The anhydrous ammonia storage vessels are filled to no more than 85% of shell volume. 
>     Anhydrous ammonia is distributed to farmers by means of U.S. Department of Transportation (U.S. DOT) permitted nurse tanks.
